title: Feature: Multi-tier favicon resolution
description:
Replace the single-source Google S2 favicon pipeline with a multi-tier resolution strategy that catches high-quality icons for major services (Gmail, etc.) that the current pipeline misses.

## Tier Strategy (server-side Convex action)

1. **Apple Touch Icon** (try first — highest quality, 180x180 PNG)
   - Direct fetch: https://{domain}/apple-touch-icon.png
   - Also try: https://{domain}/apple-touch-icon-precomposed.png
   - No HTML parsing needed, just a HEAD/GET request

2. **HTML <link> scraping** (catches site-declared icons)
   - Fetch page HTML, parse <link rel="icon|apple-touch-icon|shortcut icon">
   - Pick largest declared size (prefer 128px+)
   - Also check <link rel="manifest"> → fetch manifest.json → icons[] array
   - This is how Gmail's envelope icon is declared

3. **Third-party APIs** (reliable fallbacks)
   - Icon Horse: icon.horse/icon/{domain} (does HTML scraping server-side)
   - DuckDuckGo: icons.duckduckgo.com/ip3/{domain}.ico
   - Google S2: google.com/s2/favicons?domain=...&sz=64 (current, good for long-tail)

4. **Direct favicon.ico** (last resort)
   - https://{domain}/favicon.ico
   - Often 16x16, poor quality — only if everything else fails

## Implementation Shape

- Convex HTTP action: `fetchFavicon(url) → { iconUrl, source, size }`
- Tries each tier in order, returns first success with acceptable quality
- Quality gate: reject icons < 32x32 (triggers next tier)
- Cache results in Convex to avoid re-fetching
- Used by: "Fetch Favicons" button in settings, auto-fetch on bookmark create, icon picker

## Depends On
- brute-bookmarks-c5h (Migrate icon pipeline to Convex actions) — need server-side runtime first

## Scope
- P3 backlog — tackle after Convex icon pipeline migration is done
- Benefits all users immediately (better default icons without manual work)

title: Convex action: multi-tier favicon resolver
description:
Create convex/favicons.ts with two Convex actions:

resolveFavicon(url) — Single-domain multi-tier resolver:
1. Extract domain, check faviconCache (return if <30 days)
2. Try apple-touch-icon.png (HEAD/GET, check content-type + content-length>=100)
3. Try apple-touch-icon-precomposed.png
4. Fetch HTML (first 16KB), parse <link rel=icon|apple-touch-icon>, pick largest
5. If manifest declared, fetch manifest.json, pick largest icon
6. Try Icon Horse (icon.horse/icon/{domain})
7. Try DuckDuckGo (icons.duckduckgo.com/ip3/{domain}.ico)
8. Fallback Google S2
9. Write winner to faviconCache, return { iconUrl, source }

resolveFaviconBulk(urls) — Batch for 'Fetch Favicons' button:
- Accept array of { bookmarkId, url }, deduplicate by domain
- forceRefresh param bypasses cache
- Return array of { bookmarkId, iconUrl, source }

Reuse SSRF protection + streaming fetch patterns from metadata.ts. Zero npm deps.
URL storage (not file storage) — stores resolved URLs in iconPath field.

File: convex/favicons.ts (~200 lines new)

title: Mobile Phase 3: Infinite carousel tab groups
description:
Re-enable tab groups on mobile with infinite carousel navigation. Currently tab groups are auto-ungrouped on mobile (each category renders standalone). New design: swipe left/right on content area to cycle through tabs endlessly. Active tab always anchored on the left of the tab bar, overflow tabs fade with gradient on the right. No tab reordering on mobile — swipe replaces it.

Implementation: separate renderMobileTabGroup() function in categories.ts (desktop renderTabGroup is 175 lines of drag handlers that don't apply). Key pieces:
- rotateToActive() helper: rotates categories array so active tab is first. [A,B,C,D] with B active → [B,C,D,A]
- initTabSwipe(): pointerdown/move/up on .tab-content, 50px horizontal threshold, wraps around with modulo
- wireTabClicks(): re-wires tab click listeners after every tab bar re-render (DOM order changes on rotation)
- switchToTab closure: updates activeTabPerGroup map, re-renders tab bar innerHTML with new rotation, toggles .tab-panel-active
- CSS: .tab-bar-mobile gets mask-image gradient fade, .tab-content gets touch-action:pan-y, hide drag handle

Coexistence with long-press: long-press cancels at 10px move, swipe fires at 50px horizontal — no conflict.
